sub_topic: Calculating the enthalpy and entropy of inorganic reactions
message_1:
Calculate the standard entropy change for the reaction: 

2SO3(g) + O2(g) → 2SO4(g) 

Given the following standard entropies of formation: 

ΔS°f SO3(g) = 256.2 J/K mol 
ΔS°f O2(g) = 205.0 J/K mol 
ΔS°f SO4(g) = 296.8 J/K mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔS° = ΣnΔS°f(products) - ΣnΔS°f(reactants)

where n is the stoichiometric coefficient of each species in the balanced chemical equation.

For the given reaction:

2SO3(g) + O2(g) → 2SO4(g)

We can plug in the given standard entropies of formation (ΔS°f) for each species:

ΔS° = [2 × ΔS°f(SO4) - (2 × ΔS°f(SO3) + ΔS°f(O2))]

Now, substitute the given values:

ΔS° = [2 × 296.8 J/K mol - (2 × 256.2 J/K mol + 205.0 J/K mol)]

ΔS° = [593.6 J/K mol - (512.4 J/K mol + 205.0 J/K mol)]

ΔS° = 593.6 J/K mol - 717.4 J/K mol

ΔS° = -123.8 J/K mol

The standard entropy change for the reaction is -123.8 J/K mol.
